awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Analysis of Partial Differential Equations in Moving Interface Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Moving interfaces in multi-phase fluid flow are of significant importance, as they occur in a huge range of natural phenomena at scales from microscopic to cosmic.  Blood flow in elastic arteries, the surface of a cup of coffee, ocean waves, and solar plasma meeting the vacuum of space are just a few examples.  Fluid interfaces also play a key role in industrial and technological applications, from bubble formation in industrial emulsion manufacturing to Rayleigh-Taylor instabilities in fusion reactors.  This project aims to contribute to the understanding of these diverse and important phenomena through the mathematical analysis of the nonlinear systems of partial differential equations (PDEs) underlying these models.  The main goals of the project are two-fold.  First, the investigator will develop new mathematical tools and techniques for studying the PDEs associated with several specific models.  Second, the investigator will foster the development of a new generation of researchers through the development of an undergraduate collaborative reading and research program, as well as through course development and graduate research mentoring.

This project focuses on several specific models of viscous fluid flow: contact line dynamics, surfactant-driven flows, and gaseous stars and related models in astrophysics.  The mathematical aim in studying these models is to prove well-posedness (existence, uniqueness, and estimates of solutions), determine the stability or instability of special equilibrium configurations, and to determine the long-time behavior of solutions in the stable regime.  Analysis of each model presents novel difficulties that require the development of new techniques, schemes of a priori estimates, and basic ideas for dealing with coupled PDE systems of different type.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Moving interfaces in multi-phase fluid flow are of major importance, as they occur in huge range of natural phenomena at scales from microscopic to cosmic: blood flow in elastic arteries, the surface of a cup of coffee, crude oil floating on Gulf water, iceberg melting, solar plasma meeting the vacuum of space. They also play a key role in industrial and technological applications, from bubble formation in industrial emulsion manufacturing to Rayleigh-Taylor instabilities in fusion reactors. It is through the analysis of the nonlinear systems of partial differential equations underlying these models that mathematicians are uniquely equipped to make fundamental contributions to the understanding of these diverse and important phenomena.

During the term of this proposal, the PI wrote 17 papers in roughly seven different areas related to moving interfaces in fluids.  The PI completed three papers on the contact line problem, which concerns the dynamics of fluids with a triple interface such as one encounters in a cup of coffee where the coffee, air, and cup meet.  The PI completed three papers studying micropolar fluids, which account for microstructure such as blood cells in a fluid.  The PI wrote one paper on surfactants, which are chemicals that dynamically alter the surface tension of a fluid.  The PI wrote four papers on viscous surface waves, which model viscous fluids in a layer-like geometry subject to gravity and other physical effects.  The PI wrote two papers on the analysis of the z-pinch instability in magnetohydrodynamics.  The PI wrote two papers on the construction of traveling wave solutions to the free boundary Navier-Stokes system.  Finally, the PI wrote two papers on analysis tools related to fluid mechanics.

A major component of the grant was the PI's Collaborative Summer Analysis Program.  This provided funding for twelve undergraduate research projects during the five year term.


Last Modified: 10/24/2023
Modified by: Ian Tice
